articles.headline: Iraq’s Christians Flee as Extremist Threat Worsens
articles.snippet: Muslim fury over Pope Benedict XVI’s remarks on Islam has brought a new level of threat to an already shrinking Christian population.
articles.abstract: Muslim fury over Pope Benedict XVI’s remarks on Islam has brought a new level of threat to an already shrinking Christian population.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Oct. 16 — The blackened shells of five cars still sit in front of the Church of the Virgin Mary here, stark reminders of a bomb blast that killed two people after a recent Sunday Mass.

articles.headline: High Crime Stifles Latin Economies
articles.snippet: Rampant crime is robbing Latin America of up to 8 percent from national economic growth, economists and World Bank officials say.
articles.abstract: Rampant crime is robbing Latin America of up to 8 percent from national economic growth, economists and World Bank officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 16  Years of rampant violent crime is not only robbing Latin America of significant private investment, but in some cases is stealing up to 8 percent from national economic growth, economists and World Bank officials say.

articles.headline: Expunged Criminal Records Live to Tell Tales
articles.snippet: Electronic record-keeping is making expungement of criminal records much harder to accomplish.
articles.abstract: Electronic record-keeping is making expungement of criminal records much harder to accomplish.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 41 states, people accused or convicted of crimes have the legal right to rewrite history. They can have their criminal records expunged, and in theory that means that all traces of their encounters with the justice system will disappear.

articles.headline: Disney Says It Will Link Marketing to Nutrition
articles.snippet: Walt Disney plans to curtail the use of its name and characters with food items that do not meet new nutritional standards.
articles.abstract: Walt Disney plans to curtail the use of its name and characters with food items that do not meet new nutritional standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: Buzz Lightyear and Lightning McQueen will not be endorsing junk food much longer.

articles.headline: Old Options Still Haunt an Insurer
articles.snippet: An options grant made years ago to the new chief executive of UnitedHealth Group, Stephen J. Hemsley, is raising questions.
articles.abstract: An options grant made years ago to the new chief executive of UnitedHealth Group, Stephen J. Hemsley, is raising questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Stephen J. Hemsley joined UnitedHealth Group after 23 years with the accounting firm Arthur Andersen, he was greeted with a grant of 400,000 stock options dated shortly after he started in June 1997.

articles.headline: For the Super-Rich, It’s Time to Upgrade the Old Jumbo Jet
articles.snippet: In a market in which many owners progressively upgrade, the next big thing is the Boeing 787 Dreamliner, which lists for about $150 million and up.
articles.abstract: In a market in which many owners progressively upgrade, the next big thing is the Boeing 787 Dreamliner, which lists for about $150 million and up.
articles.lead_paragraph: The tremendously rich are different not only from you and me but also from the merely rich. For one thing, some of them have really nice airplanes.

articles.headline: It Pays to Have Pals in Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: Former PayPal employees have gone on to start or join a new generation of Internet companies and other ventures, including YouTube.
articles.abstract: Former PayPal employees have gone on to start or join a new generation of Internet companies and other ventures, including YouTube.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 — Every now and then, a group of former PayPal employees get together to catch up on life and work. It might be at a backyard barbecue, a birthday celebration at a classy San Francisco restaurant or a simple late-night reunion at someone’s house.

articles.headline: Skills Gap Hurts Technology Boom in India
articles.snippet: In a country once regarded as a bottomless well of  English-speaking engineers, a shortage looms.
articles.abstract: In a country once regarded as a bottomless well of  English-speaking engineers, a shortage looms.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIRUCHENGODE, India — As its technology companies soar to the outsourcing skies, India is bumping up against an improbable challenge. In a country once regarded as a bottomless well of low-cost, ready-to-work, English-speaking engineers, a shortage looms.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Said to Be Acquiring Chain in China
articles.snippet: The company is laying the groundwork to become the biggest foreign chain in China with the purchase of a major retailer, according to people briefed on the deal.
articles.abstract: The company is laying the groundwork to become the biggest foreign chain in China with the purchase of a major retailer, according to people briefed on the deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Oct. 17 — Wal-Mart Stores, the largest retailer in the United States, is laying the groundwork to become the biggest foreign chain in China with the $1 billion purchase of a major retailer here, according to people briefed on the deal.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Old Options Still Haunt an Insurer
articles.snippet: Article on controversy surrounding UnitedHealth Group's alleged backdating of stock options for executives focuses on practices of Stephen J Hemsley, who has taken reins at UnitedHealth from Dr William W McGuire, who was forced to resign amid crit...
articles.abstract: Article on controversy surrounding UnitedHealth Group's alleged backdating of stock options for executives focuses on practices of Stephen J Hemsley, who has taken reins at UnitedHealth from Dr William W McGuire, who was forced to resign amid criticism of how stock options were awarded; says Hemsley has not been accused of any wrongdoing; holds in shaking up management, board of UnitedHealth appeared to opt for middle way between clean sweep and retaining top executives who could continue strong track record of McGuire; says probe by Wilmer Cutler focuses on 29 option grants that accounted for nerarly 450 million stock options that company granted between 1994 and 2002; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: When Stephen J. Hemsley joined UnitedHealth Group after 23 years with the accounting firm Arthur Andersen, he was greeted with a grant of 400,000 stock options dated shortly after he started in June 1997.

articles.headline: For the Super-Rich, It’s Time to Upgrade the Old Jumbo Jet
articles.snippet: Lufthansa Technik introduces new 'VIP' design to convert Boeing 787 jumbo jet for private use, National Business Aviation Assn convention and trade show, Orlando, Fla; 787 will have 35 seats--most of which can also be used as single lie-flat seats...
articles.abstract: Lufthansa Technik introduces new 'VIP' design to convert Boeing 787 jumbo jet for private use, National Business Aviation Assn convention and trade show, Orlando, Fla; 787 will have 35 seats--most of which can also be used as single lie-flat seats, queen-size beds or double beds; jet will seat 210 to 330 passengers as commercial airliner; industry experts say that marketing interior design plans now makes sense because there is always great interest in next big thing at highest end of luxury private jet market; PrivatAir, Swiss company that markets charter and individual flights on privately configured big planes, is interested in buying 787 and is having it outfitted in true luxury; jumbo jets are often favored by Arab sheiks and other fabulously wealthy people who tend not to advertise their opulent lifestyles; Boeing 787 has list price of at least $150 million; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: The tremendously rich are different not only from you and me but also from the merely rich. For one thing, some of them have really nice airplanes.

articles.headline: High Crime Stifles Latin Economies
articles.snippet: Economists and World Bank officials say years of rampant violent crime is not only robbing Latin America of significant private investment, but in some cases is stealing up to 8 percent of national economic growth; World Bank report says that in B...
articles.abstract: Economists and World Bank officials say years of rampant violent crime is not only robbing Latin America of significant private investment, but in some cases is stealing up to 8 percent of national economic growth; World Bank report says that in Brazil, if country's homicide rate in early 1990's had been as low as Costa Rica's, which has one of lowest in region at one-sixth Brazil's rate, per capital income would have been about $200 higher and gross domestic product 3.2 to 8.4 percent higher in late 1990's; Inter-American Development Bank released in 1999 shows that across Latin America economic cost of crime is similarly pronounced, equal to 14.2 percent of region's Gross Domestic Product; bank report says crime also hurts growth by lowering productivity, high school graduation rates and labor participation; companies in oil-rich Venezuela are increasingly jittery about assaults on employees, theft at company installations and kidnapping of executives and their families; Colombia has cut homicides by 43 percent and extortive kidnappings by 82 percent since 2002 under public policy from Pres Alvaro Uribe; direct foreign investment in country more than quadrupled between 2002 and 2005; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 16 - Years of rampant violent crime is not only robbing Latin America of significant private investment, but in some cases is stealing up to 8 percent from national economic growth, economists and World Bank officials say.

articles.headline: Disney Says It Will Link Marketing to Nutrition
articles.snippet: Walt Disney Co, addressing growing concerns of parents over child nutrition, says it will curtail use of its name and characters with food items that do not meet new nutritional standards; new guidelines would limit how much sugar, calories and fa...
articles.abstract: Walt Disney Co, addressing growing concerns of parents over child nutrition, says it will curtail use of its name and characters with food items that do not meet new nutritional standards; new guidelines would limit how much sugar, calories and fat could be in snacks and foods marketed by companies that Disney has licensing relationships with; moves, which comes at time of mounting concern about childhood obesity, is likely to put pressure on companies competitors to follow suit; policy change is broadly hailed by food experts (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Buzz Lightyear and Lightning McQueen will not be endorsing junk food much longer.

articles.headline: Expunged Criminal Records Live to Tell Tales
articles.snippet: In 41 states, people accused or convicted of crimes have the legal right to rewrite history. They can have their criminal records expunged, and in theory that means that all traces of their encounters with the justice system will disappear.      B...
articles.abstract: In 41 states, people accused or convicted of crimes have the legal right to rewrite history. They can have their criminal records expunged, and in theory that means that all traces of their encounters with the justice system will disappear.      But enormous commercial databases are fast undoing the societal bargain of expungement, one that used to give people who had committed minor crimes a clean slate and a fresh start.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 41 states, people accused or convicted of crimes have the legal right to rewrite history. They can have their criminal records expunged, and in theory that means that all traces of their encounters with the justice system will disappear.

articles.headline: Iraq’s Christians Flee as Extremist Threat Worsens
articles.snippet: The blackened shells of five cars still sit in front of the Church of the Virgin Mary here, stark reminders of a bomb blast that killed two people after a recent Sunday Mass.     In the northern city of Mosul, a priest from the Syriac Orthodox Chu...
articles.abstract: The blackened shells of five cars still sit in front of the Church of the Virgin Mary here, stark reminders of a bomb blast that killed two people after a recent Sunday Mass.     In the northern city of Mosul, a priest from the Syriac Orthodox Church was kidnapped last week. His church complied with his captors' demands and put up posters denouncing recent comments made by the pope about Islam, but he was killed anyway. The police found his beheaded body on Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Oct. 16 - The blackened shells of five cars still sit in front of the Church of the Virgin Mary here, stark reminders of a bomb blast that killed two people after a recent Sunday Mass.

articles.headline: Bush Reassures Iraqi Leader
articles.snippet: The president told Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki that he would not set a timetable for withdrawal of American troops. Page A8.
articles.abstract: The president told Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki that he would not set a timetable for withdrawal of American troops. Page A8.
articles.lead_paragraph: The president told Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki that he would not set a timetable for withdrawal of American troops. Page A8.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Said to Be Acquiring Chain in China
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart Stores, the largest retailer in the United States, is laying the groundwork to become the biggest foreign chain in China with the $1 billion purchase of a major retailer here, according to people briefed on the deal.      The move represe...
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart Stores, the largest retailer in the United States, is laying the groundwork to become the biggest foreign chain in China with the $1 billion purchase of a major retailer here, according to people briefed on the deal.      The move represents a large step for Wal-Mart's strategy in China, allowing the American retailer to more than double its presence in a country that, despite its size and growing middle class, remains largely untapped by foreign retailers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Oct. 17 - Wal-Mart Stores, the largest retailer in the United States, is laying the groundwork to become the biggest foreign chain in China with the $1 billion purchase of a major retailer here, according to people briefed on the deal.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Cheney Feels the Love as He Hits the Heartland
articles.snippet: Grace Mosier lives with her mom and dad, goes to birthday parties, takes ballet classes and is just like a lot of other 6-year-old girls. Except that she happens to be obsessed with Dick Cheney.     ''I really, really like him,'' says Grace, who c...
articles.abstract: Grace Mosier lives with her mom and dad, goes to birthday parties, takes ballet classes and is just like a lot of other 6-year-old girls. Except that she happens to be obsessed with Dick Cheney.     ''I really, really like him,'' says Grace, who can tell you what state the vice president was born in (Nebraska), where he went to grade school (College View, in Lincoln) and the names of his dogs (Dave and Jackson). She gets her fix of Cheney fun-facts by visiting the White House Web site for children. It says there that his favorite teacher was Miss Duffield and that he used to run a company called Halliburton.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 12 - Grace Mosier lives with her mom and dad, goes to birthday parties, takes ballet classes and is just like a lot of other 6-year-old girls. Except that she happens to be obsessed with Dick Cheney.

articles.headline: It Pays to Have Pals in Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: Many former PayPal employees have gone on to start or join new generation of Internet companies and other ventures since 2002, when dozens of employees left company after it was bought by eBay for $1.5 billion; they have remained tight-knit group,...
articles.abstract: Many former PayPal employees have gone on to start or join new generation of Internet companies and other ventures since 2002, when dozens of employees left company after it was bought by eBay for $1.5 billion; they have remained tight-knit group, attending each other's parties, helping shape each other's business plans, backing each other's companies and recruiting each other for new projects; Silicon Valley was largely built by networks of people and companies whose interlocking relationships help to spawn new start-ups; PayPal alumni have been unusually prolific, especially given company's modest size compared to Internet giants; Internet ventures started by PayPal alumni include LinkedIn, Slide, Space Explorations Technology, or SpaceX, Yelp and YouTube, which was recently bought by Google for $1.65 billion; some former PayPal employees comment; charts; photos (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 - Every now and then, a group of former PayPal employees get together to catch up on life and work. It might be at a backyard barbecue, a birthday celebration at a classy San Francisco restaurant or a simple late-night reunion at someone's house.
